questions.text: A 30-year-old male suffers a deep laceration to the posterior thigh with complete transection of the sciatic nerve. After debridement and failed primary repair due to tissue loss, a nerve graft is planned. Which of the following is the most commonly used nerve graft in such cases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sural nerve is the most commonly used donor nerve for peripheral nerve grafting due to its length, ease of harvest, and minimal sensory morbidity.

  • Nerve grafting is indicated when:
    • There is a segmental loss of a peripheral nerve and tension-free primary repair is not possible.
    • The graft acts as a conduit to guide axonal regeneration.
  • Sural nerve:
    • Most commonly harvested for autologous nerve grafting.
    • Easily accessible and provides long graft length.
    • Harvest causes minimal sensory loss limited to lateral foot.
  • Other less commonly used donor nerves:
    • Saphenous nerve - shorter and flatter.
    • Intercostal nerve - limited in length, used mostly in brachial plexus.
    • Superficial radial nerve - limited use due to location and mixed function.

Explanation of other options:

Intercostal nerve (Option A): Typically used in brachial plexus injuries, not preferred for long segment grafts.

Saphenous nerve (Option B): Occasionally used but less ideal than sural due to smaller diameter and shorter length.

Superficial radial nerve (Option C): Rarely used for grafting due to superficial course and sensory-motor mix.

Key Takeaway:

The sural nerve is the most widely used donor nerve for grafting in peripheral nerve injuries due to ease of harvest, adequate length, and low donor site morbidity.

questions.text: Which nerve has the best prognosis after sustaining an injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Radial nerve has the best prognosis among major peripheral nerves following injury.

  • Injuries to the radial nerve, especially those occurring in the spiral groove (e.g., mid-shaft humerus fracture), are usually neurapraxias or axonotmesis, which recover well without surgery.
  • Recovery typically begins within 3-4 weeks and completes by 3-4 months in most cases.
  • In contrast, nerves like the ulnar or sciatic have poorer outcomes due to longer regeneration distances and mixed fascicular patterns.

Mnemonic for good prognosis:
GOOD NERVE

  • Grossly clean-cut injury
  • Opposed nerve ends
  • Operated early
  • Distance (short distance to reinnervate)
  • NERVE type matters - Radial > Musculocutaneous > Median > Ulnar > Sciatic

Explanation of other options:

Sciatic nerve (Option A): Longest nerve in the body, has poor prognosis due to long regeneration length.

Tibial nerve (Option B): Fair prognosis, but slower than radial; motor recovery often incomplete.

Ulnar nerve (Option C): Tends to form neuroma in continuity; poor motor recovery, especially in older patients.

Key Takeaway:
Radial nerve injuries, especially in the arm, have the best prognosis among peripheral nerve injuries.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with numbness over the lateral aspect of his upper arm following an anterior shoulder dislocation. Which nerve injury is most likely responsible for this sensory loss, described as the "regimental badge sign"?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The regimental badge sign is a classic sensory deficit associated with axillary nerve injury, causing anesthesia over the lateral upper arm.

  • The axillary nerve gives rise to the superior lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm, which supplies the skin over the deltoid region.
  • Injury to this nerve, typically following anterior shoulder dislocation, leads to sensory loss in this area, resembling the position of a regimental badge on military uniforms.
  • Motor involvement includes weakness or atrophy of the deltoid and teres minor muscles.

Explanation of other options:

Radial nerve (Option A): Sensory loss over dorsal hand and web space; not lateral upper arm.

Ulnar nerve (Option B): Affects medial hand and fingers; no involvement of upper arm.

Musculocutaneous nerve (Option D): Sensory loss over lateral forearm, not the arm.

Key Takeaway:
Loss of sensation over the lateral upper arm following shoulder dislocation suggests axillary nerve injury-called the regimental badge sign.

questions.text: Sangeetha gave birth to her first child 2 days back. She was informed by the doctor that the delivery was difficult as the shoulder of the child was stuck in the birth canal. Now, she noticed that the baby was not moving his right upper limb very well and the arm was kept close to the body, the elbow was straight and fore arm was facing to the back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classic "waiter's tip" deformity-arm adduction, elbow extension, and forearm pronation-is characteristic of Erb's palsy.

  • Erb's palsy results from injury to the upper trunk (C5-C6) of the brachial plexus.
  • It commonly follows shoulder dystocia during childbirth, where excessive traction on the neck causes stretch injury.
  • Muscles involved: deltoid, biceps, brachialis, and supraspinatus (C5-C6 supply), leading to weakness in abduction, flexion, and supination.
  • The forearm hangs by the side, extended and pronated-"waiter's tip" posture.

Explanation of other options:

Klumpke's palsy (Option A): Involves lower trunk (C8-T1), presents with claw hand, not shoulder dystocia.

Winging of shoulder (Option B): Caused by long thoracic nerve injury; scapular prominence, not arm paralysis.

Fracture clavicle (Option D): May cause swelling and crepitus but not typical "waiter's tip" deformity.

Key Takeaway:

Erb's palsy presents with the "waiter's tip"deformity due to upper trunk brachial plexus injury, commonly following difficult vaginal delivery with shoulder dystocia.

questions.text: A newborn delivered vaginally after a prolonged second stage of labor is found to have the right upper limb adducted at the shoulder, extended at the elbow, and pronated at the forearm. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the likely condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
While Erb's palsy can occur following vaginal delivery, especially with shoulder dystocia, it is not considered very common.

  • It results from injury to the upper trunk (C5-C6) of the brachial plexus. (Option A,C ruled out)
  • Characteristic posture is 'waiter's tip" or "policeman tip" deformity (arm adducted, extended, pronated).(Option B ruled out)
  • Risk factors include prolonged labor, shoulder dystocia, macrosomia, and traction during delivery.
  • Most cases are associated with difficult vaginal deliveries, but it is incorrect to state it is very common in all vaginal births.

Key Takeaway:
Erb's palsy follows upper trunk (C5-C6) injury and presents with "waiter's tip" deformity; it occurs mostly in complicated vaginal deliveries but is not very common in all vaginal births.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents after a road traffic accident with signs of brachial plexus injury. On examination, he has ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the right side of his face. What is the most likely level of nerve root involvement?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of Horner's syndrome suggests involvement of the T1 nerve root, which contributes sympathetic fibers to the head and neck.

  • Horner's syndrome indicates lower brachial plexus injury.
  • The T1 root carries preganglionic sympathetic fibers, disruption of which leads to:
    • Ptosis (drooping eyelid)
    • Miosis (pupil constriction)
    • Anhidrosis (loss of sweating)
    • Enophthalmos (sunken eyeball)
    • Loss of ciliospinal reflex
  • This clinical finding is characteristic of Klumpke's palsy (lower trunk lesion involving C8-T1).

Explanation of other options:

C8 (Option A): C8 involvement alone does not cause Horner's syndrome.

C6 (Option B): Upper trunk injury (C5-C6); not associated with Horner's signs.

C7 (Option C): Middle trunk root; not involved in sympathetic pathway to face.

Key Takeaway:

Horner's syndrome in brachial plexus injury suggests T1 root involvement, commonly seen in lower plexus injuries.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with sudden onset of pain, weakness and wasting of the muscles of the arm. She gives a history of getting a TT injection in the deltoid 5 days back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brachial neuritis (Parsonage-Turner syndrome) can occur as a post-immunization complication, such as following tetanus toxoid (TT) injection.

  • It presents with acute, severe shoulder or upper arm pain, followed by weakness and wasting of the affected muscles.
  • Sensory symptoms like paresthesia may also occur.
  • Commonly involves the upper trunk of the brachial plexus.
    Recovery is slow, typically over weeks to months, and physiotherapy is crucial.

Explanation of other options:

Radial nerve injury (Option A): Would present with wrist drop and sensory loss, not diffuse arm wasting or shoulder pain.

Abscess around brachial plexus (Option B): Rare and would present with systemic signs like fever and localized swelling.

Intramuscular abscess (Option D): Localized pain and swelling at injection site with systemic signs, not diffuse weakness or wasting.

Key Takeaway:

Brachial neuritis is a rare but recognized complication of immunization and presents with acute shoulder pain followed by weakness and wasting.

choices.text: Preganglionic injury has a better prognosis than postganglionic injury
Erb's palsy causes weakness of the abductors and external rotators of the shoulder
The Histamine test can be used to differentiate preganglionic and postganglionic injuries

questions.text: All are true regarding brachial plexus injury except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Postganglionic brachial plexus injuries have a better prognosis because surgical exploration and repair are possible.

  • In preganglionic injuries, the spinal nerve roots are avulsed from the spinal cord, making direct repair impossible.
  • Erb's palsy (upper trunk injury - C5, C6) presents with paralysis of shoulder abductors (deltoid, supraspinatus) and external rotators (infraspinatus, teres minor).
  • Horner's syndrome can be seen if the T1 root is involved in lower trunk injury.
  • Histamine test can help differentiate between pre- and postganglionic lesions based on vasodilation response mediated by intact sympathetic fibers.

Explanation of other options:

Erb's palsy (Option B): True; it weakens shoulder abductors and external rotators.

Horner's syndrome (Option C): True; occurs due to T1 root involvement.

Histamine test (Option D): True; helps distinguish between pre- and postganglionic injuries.

Key Takeaway:
Postganglionic brachial plexus injuries have a better prognosis because they are accessible for surgical repair, unlike preganglionic injuries.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with anterior shoulder dislocation after a fall. On examination, he has sensory loss over the upper lateral aspect of the arm. Which of the following muscles is most likely paralyzed in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Anesthesia over the upper lateral arm is known as the regimental badge sign, which is indicative of axillary nerve injury, commonly associated with shoulder dislocation.

  • The axillary nerve supplies deltoid and teres minor.
  • Teres minor, a rotator cuff muscle, is involved in external rotation of the shoulder.
  • Therefore, teres minor will be paralyzed in this patient.

Explanation of other options:

Supraspinatus (Option A): Supplied by suprascapular nerve; initiates abduction of shoulder.

Infraspinatus (Option B): Also supplied by suprascapular nerve; responsible for external rotation.

Teres major (Option C): Supplied by lower subscapular nerve; functions in internal rotation and adduction.

Key Takeaway:
Teres minor is paralyzed in shoulder dislocation involving axillary nerve injury, presenting with the regimental badge sign.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with weakness of grip strength following trauma to the wrist. On examination, the test shown below is performed and found to be positive. Which of the following combinations of injured nerve and affected muscle is most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The image described refers to the thumb abduction test, also known as the pen test, used to evaluate the function of the abductor pollicis brevis muscle.

  • Abductor pollicis brevis abducts the thumb perpendicular to the palm and is innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve.
  • Injury to the median nerve results in the inability to lift the thumb away from the plane of the palm.
  • This leads to a positive pen test, confirming median nerve injury.

Explanation of other options:

Median nerve - Abductor pollicis longus (Option A): Abductor pollicis longus is supplied by the posterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the radial nerve.

Ulnar nerve - Abductor pollicis longus (Option B): Incorrect nerve; this muscle is radial nerve-innervated.

Ulnar nerve - Abductor pollicis brevis (Option D): Incorrect; abductor pollicis brevis is supplied by the median nerve.

Key Takeaway:
A positive pen test indicates abductor pollicis brevis weakness due to median nerve injury.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with weakness of grip after injury. The sign shown in the image is positive. Which nerve is injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows the benediction sign, which is positive in high Median N injury.

  • Benediction sign - when the patient makes a fist, the index finger and the middle finger will not flex and stand out. This looks like the gesture of the pope when he blesses people, hence called benediction sign.
  • Other signs of median nerve injury include
    • Ape thumb deformity
    • Positive pen test
    • Pointing index
    • Oschner clasp sign

Explanation of other options:

Radial nerve (Option A): Injury causes wrist drop, not the Benediction sign.

Ulnar nerve (Option B): Injury results in claw hand deformity, not pointing index.

Axillary nerve (Option C): Causes deltoid weakness and sensory loss over the upper lateral arm.

Key Takeaway:
 A Benediction sign with inability to flex the index and middle fingers on attempted fist is classic for a high median nerve injury.

choices.text: Anterior interosseous nerve - Flexor pollicis longus
Posterior interosseous nerve - Extensor pollicis brevis

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with weakness in his pinch grip and difficulty holding small objects after receiving a recent vaccination. He is unable to make an "OK" sign with his thumb and index finger. Which nerve is injured, and which muscle is involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The sign described is the Kiloh-Nevin sign (also called the OK sign), which is positive in anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) injury. AIN is a pure motor branch of the median nerve and supplies:

  • Flexor pollicis longus (FPL)
  • Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) to the index and middle fingers
  • Pronator quadratus

Injury to this nerve leads to inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb and distal interphalangeal joint of the index finger, preventing a normal "OK"sign.

  • Most cases are due to Parsonage-Turner syndrome or compression in the forearm.
  • There is no sensory loss (as AIN is purely motor).
  • The test helps differentiate from tendon rupture, where passive thumb-tip flexion by pressing on the muscle belly is absent.

Explanation of other options:

Posterior interosseous nerve - Extensor pollicis brevis (Option B): Causes finger and wrist drop; does not affect pinch or FPL.

Ulnar nerve - Adductor pollicis (Option C): Injury leads to Froment's sign, not Kiloh-Nevin sign.

Common peroneal nerve - Tibialis anterior (Option D): Causes foot drop, unrelated to hand grip or pinch.

Key Takeaway:
Inability to form the "OK" sign indicates anterior interosseous nerve injury, affecting the flexor pollicis longus and FDP.

choices.text: Deep branch of the ulnar nerve

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with pain and paresthesia after a fall on his outstretched hand. X-ray shows a fracture of the hook of the hamate. Which nerve and its branch are most likely to be injured in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The deep branch of the ulnar nerve passes through Guyon's canal and curves around the hook of hamate. A fracture of the hook of hamate can directly compress or injure this branch, leading to motor deficits involving the intrinsic hand muscles (interossei, medial two lumbricals, adductor pollicis).

  • Sensory loss may not be evident as the superficial branch of the ulnar nerve may be spared.
  • Weakness in grip strength and fine motor coordination is typical.
  • Commonly seen in racquet sports, cycling injuries, or falls.

Explanation of other options:

Median nerve - Recurrent motor branch (Option A): Vulnerable in carpal tunnel or thenar injuries, not hamate fractures.

Superficial radial nerve (Option C): Subcutaneous and lateral-injury unlikely in hook of hamate fracture.

Anterior interosseous nerve (Option D): Lies in the forearm; not related to the hook of hamate.

Key Takeaway:
Fracture of the hook of the hamate endangers the deep branch of the ulnar nerve due to its anatomical course in Guyon's canal.

questions.text: A doctor performs the "card test" by placing a card between the patient's fingers and asking them to hold it while she tries to pull it away. Which of the following muscle-nerve pairs is being tested?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The card test evaluates the function of the palmar interossei, which are responsible for adduction of the fingers. These muscles are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

  • During the test, inability to hold the card suggests weakness of the palmar interossei due to ulnar nerve dysfunction.
  • This is commonly impaired in ulnar nerve palsy.
  • Palmar interossei: 3 muscles that adduct digits toward the midline.
  • The ulnar nerve also supplies the dorsal interossei (abductors) and most intrinsic hand muscles.

Explanation of other options:

Palmar interossei - Median nerve (Option A): Incorrect; palmar interossei are supplied by the ulnar nerve.

Dorsal interossei - Median nerve (Option B): Incorrect; dorsal interossei are also ulnar nerve-innervated.

Dorsal interossei - Ulnar nerve (Option D): Dorsal interossei are supplied by the ulnar nerve, but they abduct, not adduct.

Key Takeaway:
The card test evaluates palmar interossei function, testing finger adduction and thereby the integrity of the ulnar nerve.

choices.text: Combined ulnar and median nerve palsy

questions.text: Froment's sign is expected to be negative in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Froment's sign is a compensatory sign used in cases of ulnar nerve injury, particularly when testing the adductor pollicis.

  • In ulnar nerve palsy, the adductor pollicis is weak.
  • The patient compensates by flexing the interphalangeal joint of the thumb using flexor pollicis longus (FPL), which is innervated by the median nerve → Froment's sign is positive.
  • In combined ulnar and median nerve palsy, FPL is also paralysed, so the patient cannot flex the IP joint of the thumb, and thus, Froment's sign becomes negative.

Explanation of other options:

Tardy ulnar nerve palsy (Option A): Involves the ulnar nerve only → Froment's sign is typically positive.

Pronator teres syndrome (Option B): Affects the median nerve → Froment's sign remains positive (FPL intact).

Guyon's canal syndrome (Option C): Ulnar nerve compressed → Froment's sign is positive due to compensation by the median nerve.

Key Takeaway:
Froment's sign is negative only when both adductor pollicis and FPL are paralysed-i.e., combined ulnar + median nerve injury.

choices.text: Seen in fractures of the Lateral condyle of the humerus

questions.text: False about Tardy Ulnar N palsy
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is a late-onset neuropathy resulting from nonunion of lateral condyle fractures of the humerus in children.

  • Nonunion of the lateral condyle leads to progressive cubitus valgus deformity due to growth arrest of the lateral distal humeral physis. (Option A ruled out)
  • Over time, this valgus deformity stretches the ulnar nerve around the elbow. (Option C ruled out)
  • The term "tardy" signifies that this condition develops months to years after the initial injury.

Key Takeaway:
Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is a delayed complication of lateral condyle fracture nonunion, not malunion, and is associated with progressive cubitus valgus deformity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with ulnar nerve injury is unable to move his middle finger side to side in the coronal plane during a clinical test, as shown in the image. Which muscle must be paralysed for this test to be positive?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The Egawa test is used to assess ulnar nerve function, particularly the dorsal interossei of the middle finger.

  • The patient is asked to move the middle finger side-to-side (radial and ulnar deviation) in the coronal plane.
  • This action is solely performed by the dorsal interossei of the middle finger.
  • If these muscles are paralysed (as in ulnar nerve palsy), the patient cannot perform this movement, resulting in a positive Egawa test.

Explanation of other options:

Palmar interossei (Option B): Responsible for finger adduction, not lateral movement of the middle finger.

Lumbricals (Option C): Flex MCP and extend IP joints; not involved in coronal plane motion.

FDP medial half (Option D): Flexes DIP joints; not tested in the Egawa test.

Key Takeaway:
The Egawa test evaluates dorsal interossei function and becomes positive in ulnar nerve injury when side-to-side movement of the middle finger is lost.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with claw hand deformity secondary to nerve injury. The splint shown in the image is applied as part of the management. Identify the splint and the nerve involved.
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The image shows a knuckle bender splint, which is specifically used in ulnar nerve palsy presenting as claw hand deformity.

  • In ulnar nerve injury, there is paralysis of the medial two lumbricals and interossei, leading to MCP hyperextension and IP joint flexion, typical of claw hand.
  • The knuckle bender splint corrects this deformity by flexing the MCP joints and allowing the IP joints to extend, thus preventing contractures and aiding function.

Explanation of other options:

Cock-up splint (Option A): Used in radial nerve palsy to support wrist extension.

Opponens splint (Option B): Used in median nerve injury to support thumb opposition.

Turnbuckle splint (Option D): Used for contracture correction, especially in post-burn deformities, not for claw hand.

Key Takeaway:
The knuckle bender splint is the splint of choice for claw hand seen in ulnar nerve palsy.

choices.text: Fracture of the humerus at the spiral groove
Fracture of the neck of the humerus

questions.text: A 50-year-old male suffers an injury to the right upper limb, resulting in a fracture. He is also unable to dorsiflex his wrist, and there is sensory loss over the dorsum of the 1st web space. Which fracture can cause this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of wrist drop with sensory loss over the dorsum of the 1st web space indicates radial nerve palsy. Among the listed options, a fracture of the humerus at the spiral groove is the most likely cause.

  • The radial nerve traverses the spiral groove of the humerus.
  • Injury at this level causes:
    • Weakness/paralysis of wrist and finger extensors → wrist drop
    • Sensory loss over the dorsum of the first web space
  • This is known as high radial nerve palsy and typically occurs with mid-shaft humerus fractures.

Explanation of other options:

Fracture of the radial neck (Option B): Lies distal to the radial nerve course, doesn't cause wrist drop.

Fracture of the neck of the humerus (Option C): Can injure the axillary nerve, not the radial nerve.

Fracture of both bones forearm (Option D): Doesn't affect the radial nerve at the spiral groove level.

Key Takeaway:
Wrist drop with 1st web space sensory loss after trauma suggests radial nerve injury at the spiral groove, commonly seen in mid-shaft humerus fractures.

choices.text: Fracture of the humerus at the spiral groove
Fracture of the neck of the humerus
Fracture of both bones of the forearm

questions.text: A 50-year-old male sustains a fracture in the upper limb. He is unable to extend his fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints, but there is no sensory loss. Which fracture is most likely responsible for this clinical finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Finger drop without sensory loss indicates injury to the posterior interosseous nerve (PIN), a purely motor branch of the radial nerve. The PIN lies close to the radial head and neck as it enters the supinator muscle.

  • The PIN supplies:
    • Extensor digitorum
    • Extensor indicis
    • Extensor digiti minimi
  • Injury causes inability to extend fingers at the MCP joints (finger drop).
  • No sensory loss occurs, as the PIN has no cutaneous branches.

Explanation of other options:

Fracture of humerus at spiral groove (Option A): Causes high radial nerve palsy → wrist + finger drop + sensory loss.

Fracture of the neck of the humerus (Option C): Can affect axillary nerve → deltoid weakness, not finger drop.

Fracture of both bones forearm (Option D): Doesn't typically affect PIN.

Key Takeaway:
Finger drop without sensory loss after elbow trauma indicates posterior interosseous nerve palsy, most commonly due to radial head/neck fracture.

choices.text: Deep branch of the ulnar nerve

questions.text: A 7-year-old child sustains an injury to the left forearm. The X-ray shows a fracture of the proximal ulna with anterior dislocation of the radial head. Which nerve is most likely injured in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The injury described is a Monteggia fracture, defined as a fracture of the proximal third of the ulna with associated dislocation of the radial head. The posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) is at particular risk in this injury because of its anatomical proximity to the radial neck.

  • PIN is the deep motor branch of the radial nerve.
  • It passes through the supinator muscle near the radial head and neck.
  • In Monteggia fractures, radial head dislocation can stretch or compress the PIN.

Clinical features of PIN palsy:

  • Inability to extend fingers at the MCP joints (finger drop).
  • Wrist extension may be preserved due to sparing of the extensor carpi radialis longus.
  • No sensory loss (PIN is purely motor).

Explanation of other options:

Anterior interosseous nerve (Option A): A branch of the median nerve, injured in supracondylar or proximal forearm trauma, not in Monteggia.

Deep branch of ulnar nerve (Option C): Travels in the hand, not affected by forearm fractures.

Median nerve (Option D): More likely affected in supracondylar or distal forearm injuries.

Key Takeaway:
Monteggia fractures can cause posterior interosseous nerve injury, leading to finger drop without sensory loss.

questions.text: A 42-year-old office worker presents with gradual onset of weak grip strength and numbness over the thumb, index, and middle fingers. On examination, Durkan's test is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Durkan's test (also called the carpal tunnel compression test) is the most sensitive clinical test for diagnosing Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS).

  • CTS is caused by compression of the median nerve within the carpal tunnel at the wrist.
  • Presents with paresthesia in the radial 3½ fingers, especially at night, along with weakness of grip due to thenar muscle involvement.
  • Durkan's test: Direct compression over the carpal tunnel reproduces the symptoms within 30 seconds → positive result.

Explanation of other options:

Brachial plexus neuritis (Option A): Presents with acute pain and patchy weakness, not isolated median nerve symptoms.

Anterior interosseous nerve injury (Option B): Motor deficit only, no sensory symptoms; "OK" sign affected.

Median nerve transection (Option D): Causes complete sensory and motor loss, not reversible with compression test.

Key Takeaway:

Durkan's test is the most sensitive test for diagnosing Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, a median nerve entrapment neuropathy at the wrist.

choices.text: Paresthesia of lateral 3 ½ fingers and palm

questions.text: A 45-year-old typist presents with numbness and tingling in the thumb, index, middle, and lateral half of the ring finger, especially at night. She also reports difficulty holding objects and frequent dropping of items. On clinical examination, Tinel's sign and Durkan test are positive. Which of the following is NOT a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The clinical scenario describes Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS), a compression neuropathy of the median nerve at the wrist.

  • Paresthesia in CTS is limited to the lateral 3½ fingers (thumb, index, middle, and lateral ring finger).
  • The palm is spared because the palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve arises proximal to the carpal tunnel and does not pass through it.
  • Hence, symptoms over the palm are not present in CTS.
  • Tinel's sign, Durkan's test, and Shake sign (flicking the hand relieves symptoms) are commonly positive in CTS.(Option B,C,D ruled out)

Key Takeaway:
In Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, the palm is spared due to the palmar cutaneous branch arising before the carpal tunnel.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man complains of burning pain and tingling over the sole of his foot, worse at night and after prolonged standing. He feels transient relief by stamping his foot on the ground. On examination, Tinel's sign is positive behind the medial malleolus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presentation is classic for Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome, a compressive neuropathy of the posterior tibial nerve as it passes beneath the flexor retinaculum posterior to the medial malleolus.

  • Characteristic symptoms include:
    • Burning pain and paresthesia along the plantar surface of the foot
    • Nocturnal worsening and relief with stamping or movement
    • Positive Tinel's sign over the tarsal tunnel
  • Common causes include:
    • Idiopathic (most common)
    • Ankle osteoarthritis
    • Inflammatory arthropathies like RA and AS
  • Treatment involves:
    • Conservative management initially
    • Surgical release of the flexor retinaculum in refractory cases

Explanation of other options:

Peripheral vascular disease (Option A): Pain is typically exertional (claudication) and not relieved by stamping; no localized Tinel's sign.

Plantar fasciitis (Option C): Pain is classically worst in the morning and localized near the heel, not burning or neuropathic in character.

Plantar fibromatosis (Option D): Presents as firm nodules in the plantar fascia, usually painless unless large.

Key Takeaway:

Burning plantar pain with relief on stamping and positive Tinel's sign behind the medial malleolus points to Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with weakness in pushing objects. On examination, he is asked to press his palms against a wall, during which the medial border of his right scapula becomes prominently elevated. What is the most likely nerve involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The clinical scenario describes winging of scapula, which occurs due to paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle, supplied by the long thoracic nerve.

  • The long thoracic nerve (nerve of Bell) arises from roots C5-C7 and travels along the thoracic wall to supply serratus anterior.
  • Serratus anterior anchors the medial scapular border to the chest wall.
  • Injury causes:
    • Medial scapular border protrusion ("winging")
    • Weakness in pushing movements (e.g., wall push test)
  • Common causes of injury:
    • Trauma
    • Repetitive overhead arm movements
    • Iatrogenic injury (e.g., lymph node dissection, chest tube insertion)

Explanation of other options:

Suprascapular nerve (Option A): Supplies supraspinatus and infraspinatus-leads to shoulder abduction and external rotation weakness, not scapular winging.

Infrascapular nerve (Option B): Not a standard anatomical term; possibly intended to refer to branches to teres major/minor-does not cause winging.

Musculocutaneous nerve (Option C): Supplies anterior arm muscles-causes elbow flexion weakness, not scapular movement issues.

Key Takeaway:
Scapular winging on pushing against a wall is due to serratus anterior paralysis from long thoracic nerve (nerve of Bell) injury.

questions.text: A 38-year-old office worker presents with vague forearm pain and paresthesia in the lateral three fingers. His symptoms worsen with repetitive pronation and gripping activities. Phalen's test is negative. Which nerve is most likely compressed in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The clinical features are suggestive of Pronator Teres Syndrome, which is a proximal median nerve entrapment.

  • Caused by compression of the median nerve between the two heads of the pronator teres muscle.
  • Common in activities involving repetitive pronation and supination (e.g. computer work, manual labour).
  • Unlike carpal tunnel syndrome, Phalen's and Tinel's signs are usually negative.
  • There may be weakness in forearm pronation and finger flexion.

Explanation of other options:

Ulnar nerve (Option A): Entrapment causes symptoms in the medial 1½ fingers, not forearm pain.

Radial nerve (Option C): Compression presents with wrist drop or finger drop, not hand paresthesia.

Axillary nerve (Option D): Injury leads to deltoid weakness and shoulder sensory loss.

Key Takeaway:
Pronator teres syndrome is a proximal median nerve compression, distinct from carpal tunnel syndrome by its site, signs, and provoking movements.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with buttock pain radiating down the posterior thigh, aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down. There is no spinal tenderness. Which nerve is most likely compressed in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The clinical presentation is characteristic of piriformis syndrome, a non-discogenic cause of sciatic pain.

  • It is caused by compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle as it exits the greater sciatic notch.
  • Unlike sciatica due to disc herniation, spinal tenderness is absent, and neurological deficits are usually mild or absent.
  • Pain is worsened by prolonged sitting, climbing stairs, or hip internal rotation.

Explanation of other options:

Common peroneal nerve (Option A): Entrapment occurs at the fibular head, not in the gluteal region.

Tibial nerve (Option B): Can be compressed in the tarsal tunnel, not under the piriformis.

Lateral plantar nerve (Option D): Terminal branch of tibial nerve, involved in foot neuropathies.

Key Takeaway:
Piriformis syndrome causes sciatic nerve compression in the gluteal region and mimics radiculopathy without spinal involvement.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with pain radiating from the neck to the right upper limb along with paresthesia. On examination, the radial pulse diminishes when the patient turns his head to the affected side and takes a deep breath. What is the name of this test, and the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The clinical scenario describes Adson's test, which is performed to diagnose Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS).

  • In Adson's test, the patient is asked to rotate the head toward the affected side while extending the neck and taking a deep breath.
  • A positive test is indicated by a diminished or absent radial pulse, due to compression of neurovascular structures.
  • TOS is caused by compression between the clavicle, first rib, and scalene muscles.
  • Structures commonly compressed include:
    • Brachial plexus (most common - ~95%)
    • Subclavian artery
    • Subclavian vein

Explanation of other options:

Phalen's test - Carpal tunnel syndrome (Option A): Involves wrist flexion to elicit median nerve symptoms.

Allen's test - Raynaud's syndrome (Option B): Assesses radial and ulnar artery patency, not used in TOS.

Spurling's test - Cervical spondylosis (Option D): Tests for cervical radiculopathy by axial compression of the neck.

Key Takeaway:
Adson's test is used to diagnose Thoracic Outlet Syndrome, which most commonly compresses the brachial plexus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with burning pain in the forefoot, especially between the third and fourth toes. On clinical examination, compression of the metatarsal heads elicits a palpable click. What is this sign called, and what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation is classic for Morton's neuroma, also known as Morton's metatarsalgia.

  • It results from compression of the interdigital nerves under the transverse intermetatarsal ligament.
  • Most commonly affects the third web space (between 3rd and 4th toes).
  • Characteristic features:
    • Burning/tingling pain in forefoot
    • Worse with walking/tight shoes
    • Mulder's click: A Palpable click is elicited when squeezing metatarsals together.

Explanation of other options:

Finkelstein's test - De Quervain's tenosynovitis (Option B): Test for pain over the radial styloid during thumb flexion and ulnar deviation.

Cozen's test - Tennis elbow (Option C): Pain on resisted wrist extension indicates lateral epicondylitis.

Reverse Cozen's test - Golfer's elbow (Option D): Pain on resisted wrist flexion indicates medial epicondylitis.

Key Takeaway:
Mulder's click is pathognomonic of Morton's neuroma, a painful interdigital neuroma of the forefoot, most commonly at the 3rd web space.

questions.text: A 32-year-old cyclist presents with weakness of grip and hand clumsiness after participating in a 3-day cycling event. He has no sensory complaints. Examination atrophy of the hypothenar muscles. Which nerve is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The patient's symptoms are suggestive of Guyon's canal syndrome, commonly known as handlebar palsy.

  • This occurs due to prolonged pressure over the ulnar nerve at Guyon's canal, typically from gripping handlebars during long-distance cycling.
  • The deep branch of the ulnar nerve, which is purely motor, gets compressed.
  • Hence, patients have:
    • Motor deficits: weakness of intrinsic hand muscles, clawing of the ulnar two fingers.
    • No sensory loss, since the superficial branch (which is sensory) is usually spared.

Explanation of other options:

Median nerve (Option A): Affects the thenar muscles and causes sensory loss in the lateral 3½ fingers-doesn't match the clinical picture.

Radial nerve (Option C): Causes wrist drop and sensory loss over the dorsum-not involved in intrinsic hand muscle function.

Axillary nerve (Option D): Innervates deltoid and teres minor-not involved in grip or claw hand.

Key Takeaway:
Handlebar palsy = Compression of the deep motor branch of the ulnar nerve in Guyon's canal, commonly seen in cyclists.

questions.text: Which is not a part of Horner's syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Enophthalmos and not exophthalmos is a part of Horner's syndrome.
  • Horner's syndrome is composed of the following
    • Ptosis
    • Loss of Ciliospinal reflex
    • Enophthalmos
    • Miosis
    • Anhydrosis
  • It is usually seen in lower brachial plexus palsy, such as Klumpke's palsy, where the T1 nerve root is involved.
  • This is because Horner's syndrome occurs due to the paralysis of the sympathetic nerve to ipsilateral face that arises from T1 nerve root.

Reference: Miler's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 1537

choices.text: Congenital anomaly of the upper limb

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with an acute onset of severe shoulder pain following a viral illness, which is later followed by patchy weakness and sensory loss over the upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
This clinical picture is classical for Parsonage–Turner syndrome, which is a brachial plexus neuritis.

  • It is an idiopathic inflammatory condition of the brachial plexus.
  • Commonly presents with a sudden onset of intense shoulder pain, followed by patchy motor weakness and sensory disturbances.
  • The pain typically subsides in a few days, but neurological deficits persist.
  • Often follows viral infections, vaccinations, or surgical interventions.

Explanation of other options:

Ischemia of upper limb (Option A): Presents with pallor, pulselessness, and no neural deficits.

Congenital anomaly of upper limb (Option C): Present at birth, not post-viral or painful.

Congenital heart disease (Option D): Irrelevant to upper limb neurology.

Key Takeaway:
Parsonage-Turner syndrome is an acute brachial plexus neuritis, typically post-viral, with shoulder pain followed by upper limb weakness.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with isolated weakness in external rotation of the shoulder. MRI shows a ganglion cyst compressing a nerve in the spinoglenoid notch. Which nerve is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The suprascapular nerve traverses both the suprascapular notch and the spinoglenoid notch. Entrapment at the spinoglenoid notch selectively affects the infraspinatus muscle, leading to isolated weakness in external rotation without abduction deficit.

  • Compression at the suprascapular notch → affects both the supraspinatus and infraspinatus → loss of abduction initiation and external rotation
  • Compression at the spinoglenoid notch → affects only the infraspinatus → loss of external rotation, but abduction is preserved

This anatomical pathway makes the suprascapular nerve the only nerve at risk at both notches.

Explanation of other options:

Axillary nerve (Option A): Runs through the quadrangular space, supplies the deltoid, not involved in the spinoglenoid notch.

Infrascapular nerve (Option C): No such named nerve anatomically exists.

Nerve to subclavius (Option D): Supplies the subclavius muscle, unrelated to scapular notches.

Key Takeaway:
The suprascapular nerve is the only nerve that can be entrapped in both suprascapular and spinoglenoid notches, affecting the shoulder rotator muscles.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of tingling and numbness in the lateral three fingers, worse at night. The clinician performs a test by compressing the carpal tunnel with both thumbs for 30 seconds. This reproduces the symptoms. Which of the following tests does not evaluate for the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The clinical presentation is consistent with Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS), a median nerve compression at the wrist. Among the listed tests:

  • Durkan test: Also called the Carpal Tunnel Compression Test, where direct pressure is applied over the carpal tunnel → provokes symptoms in CTS.(Option A ruled out)
  • Phalen test: Wrist is flexed to 90° for 30-60 seconds → tingling in median nerve distribution if positive.(Option B ruled out)
  • Tourniquet test: Inflating a cuff above systolic pressure reproduces symptoms due to ischemic compression of median nerve.(Option C ruled out)
  • Allen test: This is not a test for CTS. It is used to assess arterial patency of radial and ulnar arteries before procedures like arterial blood sampling.

Key Takeaway:
Allen's test is a vascular test and not used for diagnosing Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, unlike Durkan's, Phalen's, or Tourniquet tests.
